title: Ticket #7869: Debian and Ubuntu should have distinct version numbers across distros
description: The Debian and Ubuntu packages should have unique version numbers across distros within a single build. Then we can follow Debian and Ubuntu standard practices and have packages for all the distros in a single repository. Also, htcondor would get updated when doing a version updated
remarks:
2020-Oct-13 10:30:12 by matyas:
It feels like there are multiple changes in this commit -- what's the difference between a 'full' build and a 'binary' build, why you're using dch for one but not the other, etc. Could you explain?

2020-Oct-19 08:27:15 by tim:
So, Debian and Ubuntu have all versions in a repository. So, the version number must be different between stretch and buster and xenial, bionic, and focal. The convention is to add a +b1, +b2 to binary rebuilds and to increment the release modifier 8.8.11-1.1, 8.8.11-1.2 for rebuilds which include Debian source package changes.

So, for the code, the dch in the block of code before the changes sets the base changelog entry for the build. If you are just doing a binary rebuild with no changes to Debian spec files, you use dch to bump the version in the changelog. If there are spec file changes, then you have to do a build including the sources.

So, a binary build just produces the binary packages. No source packages are produced, because they are already available.

A full build creates binary and source packages.

Every build uses dch to set the changelog. However, dch is used to bump the version number when neeeded.

2020-Oct-19 13:04:38 by matyas:
Makes sense. OK, looks good. Review passed.
